entry.title: Getting started with Machine Learning
entry.content:
Updated January 17, 2016 (GitHub repo if you prefer)

Thereâ€™s a been a lot of attention directed to AI and Machine learning lately so Iâ€™d like to collect great materials to get you up to speed.

Ping me if something is missing or shouldnâ€™t be here.

Courses

Andrew Ngâ€™s courseâ€Šâ€”â€Šhttps://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning

Andrew Ngâ€™s CS229 Stanford courseâ€Šâ€”â€Šhttp://cs229.stanford.edu/materials.html

Practical Machine Learning (part of PML, from John Hopkins University) is a lighter version compared to Andrew Ngâ€™s ML class, with a little overlapâ€Šâ€”â€Šhttps://www.coursera.org/learn/practical-machine-learning

ANâ€™s ML class is a lot more advanced regarding algorithms, so requires more rigorous background knowledge and skills.

PML is Practical, uses the language R, which is widely used in Predictive Analytics field in the industry.

ML is for more CS focused folks, uses Octave (Matlab-like language).

You can use WEKA library if you use Java to develop. WEKA is wrapped also in R as well as in Python. But both R and Python has tons of ML libraries already.

NLP

Natural Language Processing by Dan Jurafsky & Christopher Manning â€“ https://www.coursera.org/course/nlp

Two books seem to be fundamental in this field:

  • Speech and Language Processing, by Chris Manning & Hinrich SchÃ¼tze
  • Foundations of Statistical Natural Language Processing, by Daniel Jurafsky & James H. Martin

Datasets

  • https://www.kaggle.com
  • https://www.githubarchive.org/ â€“ “GitHub Archive is a project to record the public GitHub timeline, archive it, and make it easily accessible for further analysis.”
  • https://commoncrawl.org/ â€“ “We build and maintain an open repository of web crawl data that can be accessed and analyzed by anyone.”

Neural networks

  • http://deeplearning.net/tutorial/
  • http://karpathy.github.io/neuralnets/
  • http://karpathy.github.io/2015/05/21/rnn-effectiveness/
  • http://techblog.netflix.com/2014/02/distributed-neural-networks-with-gpus.html
  • http://tensorflow.org/

Fun projects

  • http://www.r2d3.us/visual-intro-to-machine-learning-part-1/
  • https://github.com/kaishengtai/neuralart
  • https://github.com/ryankiros/neural-storyteller
  • https://github.com/facebook/MazeBase

Jobs

  • Machine Learning Engineer @mattermark â€“ https://jobs.lever.co/mattermark/2f9c8c35-c9eb-4201-880a-886f77362d25

Misc

  • OpenAI Reddit AMA (January 9, 2016) â€“ https://www.reddit.com/r/MachineLearning/comments/404r9m/ama_the_openai_research_team/
  • Greg Brockman’s resource list â€“ https://github.com/gdb/kaggle#resources-ive-been-learning-from
  • Artificial Intelligence Weeklyâ€Šâ€”â€Šhttp://aiweekly.co/ 0Looking

entry.title: Getting started with ComputerÂ Security
entry.content:
I had a conversation with my uncle Michael recently about getting started with Computer Security. Here are some notes from that call. Input is very much appreciated as Iâ€™d like to make it a useful guide ðŸ¤“

Dear kids: If you want a job in 5 years, study computer science. If you want a job forever, study computer security.

— Aaron Levie (@levie) December 23, 2014

There doesnâ€™t seem to be a single place/course that is a good starting point. Field is pretty much defined by constant education, constant new attack vectors. Michaelâ€™s specialtyâ€Šâ€”â€Šforensics and identity management, sometimes border line legal work. Itâ€™s a huge field: * Cryptographyâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhy hash, why salted separately, basics (mathematical architecture) * Compression, entropy of information * Database security * Identity management

Steps to getÂ started

Identity management, Cryptography 101

Some links

Latest hacks â€“ https://h1.sintheticlabs.com/ NIST siteâ€Šâ€”â€Šhttp://csrc.nist.gov/ http://sintheticlabs.com/tools.html https://h1.sintheticlabs.com/

//update via Steve Woodrow

  • Ryan McGeehanâ€™s set of blog posts (security in the context of growing companies)â€Šâ€”â€Šhttps://medium.com/@magoo
  • OWASPâ€Šâ€”â€Šhttps://www.owasp.org

Security courses at universities:

  • https://crypto.stanford.edu/cs155/syllabus.html

  • 6.857: Computer and Network Security – Massachusetts Institute of Technology – Spring 2015 â€“ http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.857/2015/handouts

  • 6.858 / Fall 2015 / Schedule â€“ http://css.csail.mit.edu/6.858/2015/schedule.html
